newsitem.title: USA: U.S. crude diffs ease late on refinery run cuts.
newsitem.headline: U.S. crude diffs ease late on refinery run cuts.

text.p: U.S. crude differentials eased late Tuesday on softer refinery runs while outright prices were only modestly lower tracking crude futures.

In addition to a weekend fire at BP's Toledo, Ohio, refinery, which left more crude supplies for Midwest markets, the American Petroleum Institute (API) report showed a drop in crude runs to 92.7 percent, down 2.2 percent.
A combination of problems at BP's refinery and scheduled autumn turnarounds was seen slowing near-term demand.
November West Texas Intermediate/Cushing was at $25.40-50 a barrel, down five cents from Monday's cash market.
Domestic crude prices held to a steady erosion over the day led lower by the stumble in Light Louisiana Sweet.
"The ramifications of BP's problems took the grades lower," an oil broker said.
BP said Tuesday there were no changes in the status of the 155,000 barrels per day (bpd) Toledo facility, where crude runs were curtailed by a fire on Saturday.

Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James eased from the morning's 54-cents premium level against WTI, to 52 cents later, down from highs on Monday at 65 cents. Heavy Louisiana Sweet/Empire traded at 40 cents, down nine cents from previous trade.
Midland/WTI also drifted lower, selling at four cents over WTI, compared with seven cents earlier.
Heavier grades like West Texas Sour/Midland declined to minus $1.38, off six cents from earlier morning levels.
The API report for crude was neutral with slight draws in most regions and a total draw of 417,000 barrels nationwide.
But the market's obsession with shortages of heating oil, coupled with a fall in crude runs, were viewed likely to keep the crude and products uptrend broadly intact.
